Reference values¶

A number of reference values are avaliable through isopy.refval that are useful for geochemists. All the reference values are readonly to avoid corrupting the values but dictionaries can be edited by creating a copy.

Most of the reference values are IsopyDict or ScalarDict dictionaries that use isopy key string as keys and therfore will automatically format key strings.

Below is a list of the different reference values avaliable.

refval.mass¶

A collection of reference values relating to the mass number.

mass.isotopes

Dictionary containing all naturally isotopes with a given mass number.

refval.element¶

A collection of reference values relating to the element symbol.

element.isotopes

Dictionary containing all naturally occurring isotopes for each element symbol.

element.all_symbols

A tuple of all the element symbols.

element.symbol_name

Dictionary containing the full element name mapped to the element symbol.

element.name_symbol

Dictionary containing the element symbol mapped to the full element name.

element.atomic_number

Dictionary containing the atomic number for each element symbol.

element.atomic_weight

Dictionary containing the atomic weight for each element symbol.

refval.isotope¶

A collection of reference values relating to individual isotopes.

isotope.mass

Dictionary containing the default mass of each isotope.

isotope.abundance

Dictionary containing the default abundance of each isotope.

isotope.mass_W17

Dictionary containing isotope mass of each isotope from Wang et al. (2016).

isotope.best_abundance_measurement_M16

Dictionary containing the best avaliable abundance measurement of each isotope from Meija et al. (2016).

isotope.initial_solar_system_abundance_L09

Dictionary containing the inital solar system abundance of each isotope from Lodders et al. (2019).

isotope.initial_solar_system_absolute_abundance_L09

Dictionary containing the absolute inital solar system abundance of each isotope from Lodders et al. (2019).

isotope.sprocess_abundance_B11

Dictionary containing the estimated s-process abundance of each isotope from Bisterzo et al. (2011).
